climbs.name: Waganupa
climbs.fa: Stan Miller, Todd Burrill, Tim Laughlin

content.description:
Don't underestimate this one; difficult pro and hard for the grade, this one will take you for a ride.

P1) Hunt for the protection in pockets and cracks while ascending the face between Ghetto Blast and The Great Hot Blast. Ends at the right hand edge of the belly button, where you go left to the anchor above Ghetto Blast.

P2) Heading back right to where the first pitch went left, you will find a bolt, the first in a line of four which takes you up the face to the right of the belly button. Keep your head after the fourth bolt, the angle eases, but so does the pro.
content.protection: 4 bolts, bolted anchors. RP's (peanuts/micros) to 3". Tricams, ballnuts and offset nuts shine on this one.
content.location: The face between Ghetto Blast and The Great Hot Blast. Protection is...difficult, when you see it, take it. Rap the route.

content.description: It's a toprope, but...it's awesome fun toprope. Shares the anchor with Boris and first pitch of Jelly Belly. 10' (+/-) to the left of Boris, head straight up to the old anchors. Easiest way there is up Training wheels.
content.location: To the left of Boris. Options are big, a fun place to play.

climbs.name: Training Wheels
climbs.fa: Ricky Miller, Matt Brunelli, Dennis Cobb

content.description: 30' to the right of the Regular Route is a left slanted ledge of rotten rock. Staying off off the rotten section to the left, head to the short right facing dihedral and up the exposed badly protected but easy face to the right traversing ledge. Head to the good anchor at the rear of the ledge on the edge of the belly. It is easier to see all of this as you approach the base.
content.protection: Standard gear to 2". Tricams for the pockets work well.
content.location: In between the Regular Route and Boris. Rap from the newer anchors to the rear of the ledge above 'Boris'.

content.description:
One of the longest and most fulfilling lines at the crag ascends a wonderful set of cracks and face in between  the 'Sweet Cracks' and the belly button.

P1) Start the Regular Route, but instead of breaking left, head up into a 5.8 right facing corner above the ledge. At the top of the corner build a  belay on a comfortable ledge.

P2) From the belay, climb the face up and to the right to the start of a thin crack. The crack ends at a large ledge. Gear belay.

P3) Move the belay up (4th class) and to the right to a crack at the base of a left facing corner. This crack finishes at the top of the crag.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3". Doubles of fingers and hands. Offset nuts, shoulder length slings,  and tricams work well.
content.location: Starts on the Regular Route. Walk off to the back and down the east scree and talus field. Better to have your approach shoes, the walk-off is TERRIBLE, UGLY, ETC.!

content.description:
This could be a classic, but for a few sections of less than stellar rock, and a really ugly walk off one would rather forget. This is the longest and straightest route on the belly. The upper pitches are gear belays.

P1) Starting about 10' to the right of Boris, look for a shallow scoop with minimal pro above which you will pass 2 bolts and tend left along the underside of the bulge of the 'belly'. Find your way to a large ledge, shared by 5 routes and 2 sets of anchors. Belay from the upper right set of chains.

P2) Tend left and up past 2 more bolts, then right into the base of the crack (can be hard to see from the second bolt). Build a belay when you are on the left side of the belly button itself.

P3) Staying pretty straight up along the edge of the 'button', continue up the crack to the ledge at the base of a left facing dihedral/corner.

P4) Chase this fun crack up to the summit of the crag.
content.protection: Double rack .3-3". Offset nuts, slings, tricams are all useful.
content.location: 10' right of 'Boris'. If you stand back from the crag you can spy the bolts of the first pitch, and where it heads. The walk off is pretty terrible, loose talus/scree to climbers right.

content.description:
This is the left variation of (the second pitch of) Sympathetic Hygiene.

P1) Same as Sympathetic Hygiene.

P2) Leave the belay by either climbing the unprotected 5.7 face to the right or straight up the 5.8 crack (and then break right) to the base of the thin crack.

At the top of the second pitch, two choices. You can exit right across the 3rd class ramp to the anchors at the top of 'Sweet Crack Center', or finish 'Sympathetic Hygiene' and do the really lousy walk-off.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", doubles in fingers and hands.
content.location: Same as 'Sympathetic Hygiene'. To reiterate, the walk off is (short and) ugly/terrible. The climb is awesome, and should be done at least once.

content.description:
The original route on the belly proper. First pitch start is well bolted, leading to a section of thin, difficult to spot pro to a bolted hanging belay. Second pitch has 2 bolts, and intermittent gear, heady.

P1) 95' Climb through six bolts and thin gear to a bolted hanging belay.

P2) 85' 2 bolts interspersed with gear, some sketchy. The pitch wanders, look for the seam, anchors are hard to spot from below.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", 6 bolts, many small nuts and slings.
content.location: The second to last bolted line on the right side of the belly, about 35' up slope from Ghetto Blast. Rap the route.

content.description:
Uphill and to the right of Crisis Line about 20', 5 bolts and intermittent gear lead the belay shared with Crisis Line.

P1) 80'. 5 bolts lead to the scoop at the bottom of the belly button. Micro pockets, thin seams, and bold climbing.

P2) 75'. Climb straight up the right side crack of the belly to a bolt which protects the 10.c roof move, then up through unprotected face climbing to the anchor shared with Crisis Line.
content.protection: 5 bolts, bolted anchor, micro to 1 1/2" rack.
content.location: The second bolted line from the toe of the crag to the right and up the scree. First bolt is visible from the start, 12' up. Rap the route.

content.description:
Steep and fun, another bold Laughlin line on the Belly.

P1) 90'. Around 10' right of Jelly Belly, below the belly button proper, locate a line of bolts trending left and then back right, to the chains in the scoop below the belly button. Sustained 11, the real crux comes after the 6th bolt.

P2) 70'. From the belay, head up the belly button ramp leaning left to a bolt, then clip a second bolt before pulling over the bulgy/roof, then past a third bolt through unprotected 5.9 to the belay.
content.protection: 9 bolts, bolted belay. Thin gear to 1", tricams and ballnuts helpful.
content.location: 10' right of Jelly Belly, the first line on the right hand upside of the toe of the crag. The first bolt is visible from the ground, the second is close above it. Rap the route.

climbs.name: Boris
climbs.fa: Tim Laughlin, Dave Caunt, Sean Kenny

content.description: Yet another great Laughlin & co line, this one ascending a well protected line of 6 bolts. There are two sets of anchors, the ones in the back are newer.
content.location: Look for the lowest hanger to the left of the  toe of the crag. This is the first bolt of Boris. Rap from the chains on the upper right wall.
